title: Bitcoin's hashrate and mining difficulty near all-time highs, hinting at increased mining activity ahead of halving
content:
Two key metrics of bitcoin’s mining activity - hashrate and difficulty - have both reached near all-time highs ahead of the halving event.<br data-v-f87c67ca="">
<br data-v-f87c67ca="">
Bitcoin’s hashrate, or the network’s processing power, has risen to over 116 million TH/s (tera hashes per second) as compared to around 95 million TH/s in late March. <br data-v-f87c67ca="">
<br data-v-f87c67ca="">
Alejandro De La Torre, VP at Poolin, also expects bitcoin’s hashrate to hit "record highs in the coming days because this is miners' last chance to get 12.5 BTC reward ahead of the halving."

Mining difficulty

Bitcoin’s mining difficulty, an indicator of competition among bitcoin miners, also touched 16.10 trillion (T) today, as compared to its all-time high of 16.55 T recorded in March.

It suggests that more miners have joined the race ahead of the halving, which will see mining reward per-block reduce from 12.5 BTC to 6.25 BTC. The halving is expected to occur next week on May 12.
